titleStmt.title: Letter from William F. Cody to Samuel Stone "Buckskin Sam" Hall, May 23, 1879

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

notesStmt.note: Winfred Blevins, DICTIONARY OF THE AMERICAN WEST (Sasquatch Books, 2001), was my source for defining Cody's Westernisms here.

bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Letter from William F. Cody to Buckskin Sam Hall

msIdentifier.repository: McCracken Research Library, Buffalo Bill Center of the West

div1.p:
Yours at hand I have but a few moments to write you. I just came in from my ranch for the balance of my outfit chuck & c.1 for the round up start out in two hours have a hundred different things to get together. WontWon't have time to read Cody's Corrall2 but will take it with me. and read it on the prairie. probalyprobably it
will go better there. You say your health is bad. if I had you to fork some of my pitching horses3 and go it on corn bread straight in this great and glouriousglorious climate for a few months I would fix you.
Will old Pard probalyprobably some time we will hoof it up together some time over the prairie. this is the boss life to lead.
Excuse haste. Take the will for the deed

back.note: Note 1: Cody refers to resupplying food ("chuck") for his "outfit" of riders on the ranch.

Note 2: Cody most likely refers to the poem "Cody's Corral, or, the Scouts and the Sioux," which was later reprinted in programs for Buffalo Bill's Wild West as early as 1885. The 1885 program gave credit for the poem to "Buckskin Sam."
Note 3: In this context, "to fork" means "to mount." "Pitching" is apparently Texas slang for what other Westerners would call "bucking."
